Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208,.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, Section 28, the Court has the authority to modify a custody judgment upon a showing of a substantial change in circumstances and when such modification is in the best interests of the child.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In the case of Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court held that a modification of a custody order is appropriate when there has been a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case does not involve or decide a modification of an existing custody order based on a material change in circumstances. Instead, the SJC explicitly declines to apply the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard of G.L. c. 209C, § 20, holds that the case was tried as an initial custody determination under § 10(a), and applies a pure ‘best interests of the child’ analysis. Thus, it neither states nor adopts the rule that a modification of a custody order is appropriate upon a material change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 68 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 276 (2007)
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 68 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Additionally, in Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 276 (2007), the Appeals Court emphasized the importance of considering the child's best interests when determining custody modifications.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 68 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Bower v. Bournay-Bower and does not concern custody or the best interests of a child; it is a property dispute about storm water drainage, nuisance, and prescriptive easements. Nothing in the text addresses custody modifications or the child’s best interests standard. Therefore, this opinion cannot support the proposition claimed for Bower v. Bournay-Bower.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 68 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: This appeal concerns the flow of storm water through four town culverts onto the property of the plaintiffs, James and Christine Trenz. Claiming that significant amounts of water discharge onto their land causing damage, the plaintiffs brought this action against the town and a neighbor, Barbara Meacham.
